acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat dermal LD50 of > 2400 mg/kg (EHC 224, 2001), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category (Category 5 or "Not classified" category in the United Nations classification).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: The rat oral LD50 is 22 mg/kg (RTECS, 2003 original literature: Pesticide Chemicals Official Compendium, Association of the American Pesticide Control Officials, Inc., 1966).

carcinogenicity.rationale: No test results on this substance were found; however, since arsenic compounds are defined as human carcinogenic substances by the IARC (IARC Suppl. 7, 1987) and Japan Society for Occupational Health (2000), this substance was classified into Category 1A.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
Only test results on this substance available include in vitro Ames tests that gave negative results (NTPDB, accessed in February 2009; HSDB, 2003). As such classification is not possible.
The DFG has classified arsenic and its inorganic compounds into Category 3A for germ cell mutagenicity (which is equivalent to Category 1B to 2 in the GHS classification) (MAK/BAT, 2007).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Given its substance-specific UN No. 1585, the substance is rated as Division 6.1, II by the UNRTDG. Despite this information, due to lack of additional data, classification is not possible.

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: No test results on this substance were found, but according to description for arsenic and arsenic compounds documented in EHC 224 (2001) which is a List 1 information source, these substances are suggested to affect human reproduction and have teratogenic effects at doses that are toxic to maternal animals. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 2. As additional background information, the Catalog of teratogenic agents (2004), which is equivalent to List 1 sources, supports the conclusion that inorganic arsenic is not teratogenic to humans.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: This substance belongs to an inorganic arsenic compound group. Since inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to irritate human eyes (HSG 70, 1992; PIM 042, 1996), the substance was classified into Category 2.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: No data available. Inorganic arsenic compounds are reported to be irritating (DFGOT vol. 21, 2005).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: No test results are available on this substance. Although inorganic arsenic compounds may cause skin sensitization in humans, this is not a definitive conclusion (ATSDR, 2007; HSG, 1992). According to EHC 224 (2001), dermal sensitization to inorganic arsenic appears to be a rare occurrence in humans. Overall, due to insufficient study results available, the substance was classified into the "classification not possible" category.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: It is stable in contact with water. (It is insoluble in water according to Lide (88th, 2008).)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, skin)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: No test results on repeated exposure to this substance were found. However, since it belongs to an inorganic arsenic compound group, the following references were considered. According to EHC 224 (2001) on arsenic and its inorganic compounds in relation to humans, gastrointestinal tract disorder; nervous disorder; effects on the blood system; and abnormalities in cardiovascular system, kidney, and liver were observed. Thus, target organs for these substances are the gastrointestinal tract, heart, brain, and kidney. In addition, the skin, bone marrow and peripheral nervous system are also affected by these substances. Moreover, according to ACGIH (2001), the upper respiratory tract and lung are also affected. Based on these reports, this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, kidney, liver, blood system, respiratory system, and skin).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, liver)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In humans, this substance affects the nervous system (EHC 224, 2001). In addition, the following acute toxic effects by arsenic compounds are documented: symptoms of the gastrointestinal tract, cardiovascular system, nerves, and blood system; conjunctivitis and dermatitis as well as irritation to the nasal mucosa, pharynx, and trachea; frequent urination or anuria due to a blockage of renal tubules with clots of hemoglobin (IARC 23 (1980)); depression of bone marrow functions; and hepatomegaly (EHC 224 (2001)). In accordance with these reports, the digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver were considered to be target organs of these compounds, and this substance was classified into Category 1 (digestive system, circulatory system, nervous system, blood system, respiratory system, skin, kidney, and liver).
